title: Have You Tried Not Washing Your Face?

content: I’m not a medical expert, that much has been established. But I keep finding myself in situations where people ask me what I do to keep my skin so clear. My answer, every time and without failing and bluntly, is that I use steroids. There’s really no other way around it. The most substantial products I use that make a difference in how smooth my skin is will always be steroids until I make the choice to do otherwise. For the time being, I’ll remain with my last resort.

As it stands, steroids are not the last resort for some people. And I can understand not wanting to succumb to them, but also, not wanting to depend on them. I’ve recently been exposed to topical steroid withdrawal, which refers to the uncontrollable spread of dermatitis and worsening skin inflammation after disuse of steroids after you have been using them consistently. It’s not for the faint of heart. It’s a painful condition that requires a lot of strength and determination. Yes, but you also need resolve. For withdrawal and those effects.

content: And after such exposure, I did want to be especially mindful of what exactly I’m using on my face and my body. What are these things doing to my skin? What is working beyond steroids?

Nevertheless, I’m still on this journey myself, and given that I don’t know the precise science – or rhyme or reason – I’ve decided to look and try my hand at other skin care regimens and see if they hold up. One day, someone will ask what I do to have clear skin, and I might be able to have a more accessible answer. Starting with not washing my face.

The first time I heard this turn of phrase (advice) was while I was scrolling through TikTok. In an interview with a GQ reporter, actress Salma Hayek said that she does not wash her face in the morning, which had everyone up in arms, because isn’t that something everybody does? Has it not always been a habitual and obligatory part of our morning routine? Well, she isn’t the first actress to admit to as much. content: “What happens at night is your skin produces all the oils that your skin needs to look youthful. It regenerates. So, wash your skin really well at night but don't wash the hard work off your skin in the morning.”

I know people that wash their face at night before going to bed and in the morning after waking up. Some people don’t do that at all. And some count whatever they’ve done with their 17-in-one soap-shampoo-conditioner in the shower every other day as enough.

Personally, I’m obsessed with moisturizing every part of my body. Especially my face. So much so that every night, even if I don’t wash my face (which I often don’t), I will still go to the lengths to lather lotion and hydrate key dry spots with Vaseline to seal the moisture in. I can see the appeal of not washing your face in the morning, but for me, it wakes me up and makes me feel rejuvenated for the day. A rather relaxing start if you think about it.

content: Maybe it was because it was summer and my skin’s fatal flaw is dryness, or the fact that I was hot, and I was miserable, and our AC didn’t work, but opting to not wash my face in the morning felt terrible. One morning, I couldn’t open my eyes. The skin at my nose’s corner and under my eyes was rough and textured in a way that was tighter than normal. My skin felt rubbery. It didn’t feel like any moisture was being locked into my pores. It wasn’t until that moment – that feeling – that I decided this skin tip trick wasn’t one for me.

The effectiveness of this tip may lie in whether your preference is showering at night or showering in the morning. For the sake of trial and error, I would encourage you to see if Hayek is truly onto something, and most importantly, whether it works for you.
